196

I

was soon

N

asce

nella faut

12 1, 1918. 
+ sods or flot sao t3 durob

sad fra

ar. 8. 8. Kuro sets ee of yetgod bus seda 
21 Astor St. 
Boston, Mass.

or visitas 
by dear Kwan:

Thank you for your most interesting letter received this mowning.

As have already written alv. Mok, the trustees thenselves have not passed 
finally on the conferense proposition, but ina such as thº Executive Committee, 
which represents the majority of the board, had waninously recommended that 
the grounds and buildings be tumed over to the Chinese students for this

purpose, I feel confident that the trustees, at their apxing meeting to.

MOPPOW, will pass favorably on the matter. The moment that point is settled

I shall be anxious to see you or Ir. Mok and talk over arrangements. The one

great difficulty which we seem likely to face is that of supplying the neces -
sazy help at the dining hall. I imagine you will wish to make use of the 
dining hall, and as you doubtless realize, it is not an easy proposition to 
get together cooks and wai tere for a matter of a week or two only in the 
middle of the summer. We shall have to find a way to solve the problem, of 
course, and in the mean time it will doublless help matters if we can talk 
things over together and understand more full sust what is desired.

I am asking ifiss Jonos to send you a few pictures from which you 
can aelect and which I hope will prove of value in displaying to your fellow 
countrymen the charms of Andover. I only wish there was a good swimming place 
nearby, but with the pool, Pomp's Pond and the Shawsheen, all available, I 
imagine that even those who are fondest of this sport will be able to indulge 
pretty freely.

By all means keep the picture of myself which I am sending you,

pro 
Maing you can find a satisfactory place to house it. It ought to help
raw: 196 I was soon N asce nella faut 12 1, 1918. + sods or flot sao t3 durob sad fra ar. 8. 8. Kuro sets ee of yetgod bus seda 21 Astor St. Boston, Mass. or visitas by dear Kwan: Thank you for your most interesting letter received this mowning. As have already written alv. Mok, the trustees thenselves have not passed finally on the conferense proposition, but ina such as thº Executive Committee, which represents the majority of the board, had waninously recommended that the grounds and buildings be tumed over to the Chinese students for this purpose, I feel confident that the trustees, at their apxing meeting to. MOPPOW, will pass favorably on the matter. The moment that point is settled I shall be anxious to see you or Ir. Mok and talk over arrangements. The one great difficulty which we seem likely to face is that of supplying the necessazy help at the dining hall. I imagine you will wish to make use of the dining hall, and as you doubtless realize, it is not an easy proposition to get together cooks and wai tere for a matter of a week or two only in the middle of the summer. We shall have to find a way to solve the problem, of course, and in the mean time it will doublless help matters if we can talk things over together and understand more full sust what is desired. I am asking ifiss Jonos to send you a few pictures from which you can aelect and which I hope will prove of value in displaying to your fellow countrymen the charms of Andover. I only wish there was a good swimming place nearby, but with the pool, Pomp's Pond and the Shawsheen, all available, I imagine that even those who are fondest of this sport will be able to indulge pretty freely. By all means keep the picture of myself which I am sending you, pro Maing you can find a satisfactory place to house it. It ought to help

metadata.name: Phillips Academy
metadata.abstract: Letter stating that the conference idea has merit and must next be approved by the Trustees. He will then contact Kwan about arrangements; the dining facilities may pose a problem that will be solved. He mentions the swimming places that will be available. Photos will be sent by Miss Jones
metadata.note_acquisition: Phillips Academy Archives and Special Collections received the letters and materials of Sung Sing Kwan from Alfred E. Stearns in ____(date)
metadata.note_preferred-citation: From The Trustees of Phillips Academy.
metadata.collection: Head of School (Stearns) correspondence with Chinese alumni
